subject: probability
title: Central Limit Theorem
contentHtml:
The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) is a fundamental concept in probability theory that states that, given certain conditions, the distribution of the mean of independent and identically distributed random variables will converge to a normal distribution as the sample size increases.

In other words, even if the underlying distribution is not normal, the average of many samples will be approximately normally distributed. This has far-reaching implications in statistics, machine learning, and data analysis.
intuition: The CLT is often misunderstood as saying that the mean of a large sample will be normally distributed. Instead, it says that the distribution of the mean (i.e., the average) will converge to normality.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, the CLT is used to justify the use of Gaussian distributions in modeling and inference.

title: Central Limit Theorem
contentHtml:
The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) states that the average of a sufficiently large number of independent and identically distributed random variables will be approximately normally distributed.

This means that even if the individual distributions are not normal, the distribution of the mean will converge to a normal distribution as the sample size increases.

theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the sum of independent random variables can be approximated by a normal distribution using the Lindeberg-Feller theorem.

intuition: The CLT matters because it allows us to model real-world phenomena with a normal distribution, even if the underlying data is not normally distributed. This has significant implications for statistical inference and machine learning algorithms.
realWorldApplications: In natural language processing, the CLT can be used to model the distribution of word frequencies in a large corpus.

subject: probability
statementHtml: Prove that as n grows to infinity, the average of n independent identically distributed random variables with mean μ and variance σ2 converges in distribution to a normal distribution with mean μ and variance σ2.
hints: The key is to show that the sum of these random variables has a limiting normal distribution.
Use the fact that the sum of independent random variables is also normally distributed when the number of terms grows large.
You can apply the Lindeberg-Feller theorem or the Berry-Esseen theorem to prove this result.
solutionHtml:
To prove this, we'll use the Berry-Esessen theorem. First, note that each random variable has mean μ and variance σ2. Then, let's define Z as the sum of these random variables:

\[Z = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^n (X_i - μ)}{σ\sqrt{n}}.\]

We can apply the Berry-Esessen theorem to show that Z converges in distribution to a standard normal distribution.

title: Central Limit Theorem
statementHtml:
Given a sequence of i.i.d. random variables X1, X2, ..., Xn with mean μ and variance σ2, show that the sample mean \(\bar{X}_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n X_i\) converges in distribution to a normal random variable with mean μ and variance σ2/n as n → ∞.

",
hints: The key is to recognize that the sample mean is a linear combination of independent random variables.
Use the fact that the sum of independent random variables is also normally distributed if the number of terms grows sufficiently large.
You can use Chebyshev's inequality or Slutsky's theorem to prove convergence in distribution.
solutionHtml:
To prove this, we'll use a combination of the central limit theorem for sums and the continuous mapping theorem. Let Yi = Xi - μ, so that Y1, ..., Yn are i.i.d. with mean 0 and variance σ2. Then \(\bar{Y}_n = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n Y_i\) is a linear combination of independent random variables, so it converges in distribution to a normal random variable by the central limit theorem for sums. Since μ is the mean of X1, ..., Xn, we have that \(\bar{X}_n = \mu + \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n Y_i\). By the continuous mapping theorem, this converges in distribution to a normal random variable with mean μ and variance σ2/n.

",
answerShort: The sample mean converges in distribution to a normal random variable" },

subject: probability

problem.statementHtml: Prove that as n grows, the average of n independent and identically distributed random variables with mean μ and variance σ2 converges to μ.
hints: The key is to recognize that the sum of these random variables can be viewed as a linear combination of independent standard normal variables.
Use this insight to apply the Lindeberg-Feller CLT.
Show that the variance of the average converges to zero.
problem.solutionHtml:
To prove this, we can use the Lindeberg-Feller CLT. First, note that the sum of these random variables is a linear combination of independent standard normal variables:

\[5pt] \begin{align*} rac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (X_i - μ) &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i - nμ \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i - nμ + \mu \sum_{i=1}^{n} 1 \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \left( \sum_{i=1}^{n} (X_i - μ) + \mu \sqrt{n} \right). \end{align*}

Now, apply the CLT to this sum:

\[5pt] \begin{align*} \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (X_i - μ) &\xrightarrow{d}\ N(0, σ^2). \end{align*}

Finally, note that the average of these random variables is just a scaled version of this sum:

\[5pt] \begin{align*} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (X_i - μ) &= \frac{1}{n} \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} (X_i - μ) \right). \end{align*}

Since the sum converges to a normal distribution, so does the average.
problem.answerShort: The average of these random variables converges to μ

commonMistakes: Failing to recognize that the sum is a linear combination of independent standard normal variables.

title: Central Limit Theorem: A Worked Example
contentHtml: In this example, we'll apply the Central Limit Theorem (CLT) to a real-world scenario.

problem.statementHtml: A random sample of size 100 is taken from a population with mean 50 and standard deviation 10. What can we say about the distribution of the sample mean?
hints: Hint: Think about the shape of the sampling distribution.
problem.solutionHtml:
To apply the CLT, we first need to check if the conditions are met.

  • Check that the population is normally distributed. Since it's not given, we'll assume it's not normal.
  • Verify that the sample size is large enough. In this case, n = 100 is sufficient.

Now, apply the CLT: as n → ∞, the sampling distribution of the mean will converge to a normal distribution with mean μ and standard deviation σ / √n.
problem.answerShort: The sample mean will be approximately normally distributed.
